Award.AwardTitle: Student Support for Attending Gordon Research Seminar and Conference (SMCHR 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical art history is a new sub-discipline within art historical and conservation research that applies science and technology to the understanding and preservation of art objects. Only in the last decade has this community accorded image processing and computational science the status of a principal partner among the other scientific and technological disciplines, such as chemistry, materials science, physics, imaging technology, and dendrochronology, blended together in the growing specialization of technical art history.

From July 29 to August 5, 2016, a technical art history workshop funded by the Kress Foundation, a Gordon Research Seminar with the theme "Cross Disciplinary Connections in Conservation Science and Technical Art History", and the 3rd Gordon Research Conference on Scientific Methods in Cultural Heritage Research will take place sequentially. Funding from the Kress Foundation will support more than a dozen undergraduates, graduate students, and fresh post-docs to participate in the curriculum-building workshop. This proposal requests registration and travel support for eight of these continuing students and fresh post-docs - with backgrounds in engineering and science that include applicable expertise in imaging science and technology, digital signal/image processing, or computer science - to attend the Gordon Research Seminar and Conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary (and intended) outcomes of the activities supported by NSF Grant 1645564 (i.e. participation in (i) the 2016 Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) and Conference (GRC) on Scientific Methods in Cultural Heritage Research, (ii) a technical art history curriculum development workshop, and (iii) a computational art history project) are the career impacts mentioned in their statements included in the final report and indicated by their post-experience career choices. Following the GRS and GRC, two grant support recipients, Rosie Grayburn (now in the Scientific Research and Analysis Laboratory at Winterthur) and Amanda House (a recent Computer Science graduate from Cornell University) recognized the need for more cross-disciplinary communication and were inspired to organize a panel discussion at the Getty Conservation Institute with scientists and art historians about the role of computational tools in cultural heritage. Emmie Campbell (a PhD candidate in Materials Science and Engineering at Northwestern University) noted: "The opportunity to interact with leading members of the field, as well as other young researchers, has given me insights into how to direct my current research towards techniques that would be applicable both to my current research, as well as future endeavors in art conservation science. Collaborations that use these mutually-beneficial techniques will also allow me to cultivate connections that will hopefully lead to professional opportunities within art conservation science."   Alyssa Hull (then a PhD candidate in chemistry at Duke University) stated: "Attending the GRS and GRC reaffirmed my commitment to become a conservation scientist." Louisa Smieska (PhD graduate in materials chemistry from Cornell University) accepted a Mellon Foundation Conservation Fellowship at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 2016-17 and in fall 2017 became a Research Associate at the Cornell High Energy Syncrotron Source (CHESS) where a part of her duties is to enhance the involvement of CHESS in cultural heritage research activities.  Mallory Stephenson (majoring in chemistry at Washington and Lee University) while headed toward a career in medicine was prompted by her experience to explore "the interface between medicine and conservation science during my career".  The goal of Zachary Voras (PhD student, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Delaware) to pursue cultural heritage research with a focus on fine art paintings" was so reinforced by his experience at the GRS and GRC that he sought to be, and was, elected a co-chair of the 2018 GRS. Emily Frank (student in conservation graduate program at New York University) will be a co-author on two invited papers in a session on a digital art history data acquisition tool at the 2018 Conference on Information Sciences and Systems at Princeton University.  Such career-boosting effects are highly desirable, cost-effective outcomes of a primarily travel support grant from NSF.
